instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that only powers on conected to the port of UB300. In all other 3 ports it only has 5V on ampmetter, and 0.25A.

Client arrived today from flight and says that it just stoped charging the battery with no reason, and it still doesen't charge the battery..

CB306 and CB300 were burnt and his traces exploded. I've replaced UB300, but it keeps with the same behavier (it stays w/o CB306 and CB300).

RB260 was a bit burnt and I've replaced.

Strangely I have 0V on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL>, and 0 on diode reading (mesured on test pad).

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

Diode readings:
UB400:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.491
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.461
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.497
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.497

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.488
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.459
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.495
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> = 0.515
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.499

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.510
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.477
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.517
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> = 0.514
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.500

UB300:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = .521
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.3486
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_SX</SIGNAL> = 0.523
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.500

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0"
Did you really mean zero (short to ground), or OL (open)?
Open Line means there is no connection from CB306 to UB300.
May be caused by broken trace, or bad solders underneath.

BTW, CB306 is more critical than CB300.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL>= 0 ohm resistance to ground and OL on diode reading (on test pad)

CB306 traces are burnt. I can't wire it (maybe if I scratch the trace, if it is critical. Should I do it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
SORRY!!!

OL on resistance and diode reading.

I've wired the trace to the CB306 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> pad, but now I have 2.9V there and on test pad, and 0.526 on diode reading, and I get the same behavier on all other USB ports.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Then UB300 is bad, if generates 2.9V on 1V8 LDO...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Just replaced another <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (from a different board), but still have 2.9V on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> test pad, however i have 5V in all USB ports.

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> has 1.783V

Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: That's no good; you may have leakage between internal traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi. But I get OL when measuring. That should indicate that nothing is connected there, right?

I even wired on it an 1.8V line, but when Ido that, I get 1.8V but still only 5V on all ports.

When measured right after the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, I still get 3V there.

Can I do anything else?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
That voltage is internally generated by <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
It only requires an external capacitor, for stability.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
